author: DEAN RITCHIE
title: Sharks coach Shane Flanagan hits out at bad behaviour in wake of Fifita allegations | dailytelegraph.com.au
text:
CRONULLA coach Shane Flanagan has hit out at poor behaviour on the sidelines in the wake of allegations against his star player Andrew Fifita.
“We all don’t want the ugly parent in sport,” Flanagan said.
The coach was talking after learning his star prop, and his brother David Fifita, were allegedly involved in an ugly incident at a junior rugby league game where they abused and threatened a referee.
“I was at junior league yesterday,” Flanagan said.
“We all don’t want the ugly parent in sport. We want the officials to feel safe.”
PODCAST: PHIL ROTHFIELD AND DEAN RITCHIE ON THE FIFITA SCANDAL
Andrew Fifita has struggled with depression, a fact Cronulla will digest when discussing any possible punishment.
“There’s a lot of things that will go into it — the player’s welfare, his health. We all know where Andrew has been before,” Flanagan said.
“We’re not making excuses here, as the club will deal with it really strongly. As I said the right people are in control of that. I’ll coach the footy team.”
BAD BEHAVIOUR: Cronulla told Fifita twins had done it before
BUZZ: Sharks pair should be stood down
SCANDAL: Sharks CEO slams Fifita brothers
NASTY: Fifita threatens junior league ref
The Fifita brothers after Cronulla’s victory over the Bulldogs on Sunday. Source: News Corp Australia
Fifita made a number of errors in Sunday’s game against Canterbury in a performance Flanagan described as “indifferent”.
“We need all the information — we haven’t got all that as yet,” Flanagan said.
“We’ll definitely deal with it as a club and be really strong. As quick as we can do it, we’ll do it. His performance today was indifferent.
“He had some real good carries but gave away a few penalties — he had a bit on his mind I suppose.”
Sharks skipper Paul Gallen added: “I thought he tried really hard, probably too hard. He got pulled up on his play-the-ball, which is something Flanno has been telling him every week for a while.
“He’s got to fix those little things. The other stuff, I got to the bus not knowing anything about it. I make a plan of not reading the papers and staying off social media on game day.”
